byproducts.notes: Pruned branches and old trunks used for carving and smoke

seasonality: Deciduous; flowers in spring, fruit ripens in autumn
narrative: Apple trees line the valley's terraces, their spring blossoms drawing bees from miles away. Farmers graft favored varieties onto hardy rootstock, tending the orchard for five years before the first true harvest. In autumn, the Fruit-Tenders Guild inspects every barrel of cider and collects a tithe, punishing smuggling with confiscation of presses. Local folklore says that burying a wormy apple beneath your doorstep wards off roving spirits, so villagers trade bruised fruit at market despite the guild's complaints. Some elders claim the practice keeps winter famine at bay.
toxicity_notes: Seeds contain cyanogenic glycosides; avoid large quantities
foraging_notes: Grafted varieties persist in abandoned orchards
rotation_relationships: Orchards with legume ground cover enrich soil
fallow_notes: Prune annually; replant after 25 years to rejuvenate grove

narrative: Barley brewers fill casks for taverns, while poorer folk bake coarse loaves. A levy on malt drives some to hide sacks beneath straw to dodge the ale-tax.
foraging_notes: Wild barley persists along field margins
seasonality: Annual cereal; sown in spring and reaped in late summer
fallow_notes: Fields rest after two grain years

seasonality: Biennial brassica harvested for heads in first year
narrative: Cabbage patches ring many a cottage, their broad leaves glistening with morning dew. Housewives shred surplus heads for pickling crocks, while peddlers hawk brined leaves to travelers. The city levies a small tax on each cart entering the gate, so some farmers smuggle baskets hidden beneath firewood. Folklore insists a cabbage planted on the new moon grows sweetest.
foraging_notes: Wild forms cling to rocky coastal soils
rotation_relationships: Rotate with legumes and roots to deter pests
fallow_notes: Avoid planting brassicas in same bed for three years

narrative: Orange carrots are favored by nobles, though common folk still grow purple varieties. Carrot thieves often nibble tops to test sweetness before pilfering roots.

foraging_notes: Fruiting after rains; avoid false look-alikes.
seasonality: Summer to early autumn after wet weather.
narrative: Golden trumpets rising from leaf-litter; a forest prize with a rich, peppery scent.
Flax fields bloom blue before harvest, then villagers soak bundles in ponds to loosen fibers. The reeve counts every bundle to tax linen weavers.
Garlic hangs in bundles over tavern doors to ward off night walkers. Apothecaries distill its juice into tonics sold at market fairs.
foraging_notes: Strong odor reputed to repel evil

narrative: Monks prize humble lentils for Lenten fare, selling surplus to traveling mercenaries who value the quick-cooking pulse.
Breakfast gruels of oats sustain soldiers on campaign, though nobles sneer it as horse food. Traders sometimes water the grain to cheat weights.
seasonality: Annual; thrives in cool damp soils

narrative: Onion braids hang under cottage eaves to dry. Travelers say smelling an onion before battle grants courage, so soldiers tuck bulbs into belts.

foraging_notes: Grows on fallen beech logs; avoid toxic look-alikes

byproducts.notes: Spent substrate used to inoculate new logs

seasonality: Fruits in cool, damp weather; indoor beds yield year-round
rotation_relationships: Spent logs composted for vegetable beds
fallow_notes: Logs produce for three years before replacement
narrative: Oyster mushrooms bloom from damp logs like shelves of gray velvet. Woodland folk cut them with bone knives and carry the harvest to market in woven baskets. The Mycologists' Circle licenses growers, but forest hermits sometimes cultivate hidden beds to trade for salt. A superstition claims eating the first autumn flush grants prophetic dreams.
Pea plots sprout near every cottage. During festivals children compete to spit peas furthest across the green.

seasonality: Harvested when berries redden, then dried.
narrative: Dried berries from far-off vines, black and biting on the tongue; dear in any market.
Rye feeds upland villages where wheat fails. Millers watch for dark ergot kernels, lest cursed loaves bring dancer's madness.
foraging_notes: Hardy grain grown on poor soils
seasonality: Winter cereal; sown in autumn and cut midsummer
fallow_notes: Allows soil to recover from ergot

byproducts.notes: Petals yield a faint yellow dye

seasonality: Blooms in autumn after summer dormancy
narrative: Autumn-blooming saffron crocus carpets terraced hillsides in a haze of purple. Each dawn, pickers pluck the three crimson stigmas by hand, racing the sun before petals wilt. Merchant caravans purchase the threads at a premium, yet the Harvesters' Consortium restricts sales to licensed factors, punishing unsanctioned trade. Legends whisper that a single stolen bulb carries a decade of misfortune, so poachers work under masks and false names. During lean winters, villages hoard dried strands to spice thin porridge. Some alchemists barter secret cures for a pinch of the spice.
foraging_notes: Harvest stigmas at dawn before petals close
rotation_relationships: Rotate with cereals to prevent soil exhaustion
fallow_notes: Fields rest after four years of continuous saffron

narrative: Turnip lanterns light harvest festivals. The lord claims every tenth cart for his winter stores, so villagers stash roots in forest pits to escape levy.

byproducts.notes: Kernel yield from a single plant
Stems bundled for thatch or fodder

narrative: Rolling fields of wheat wave golden before the midsummer harvest. Village reeves tally each sheaf for the lord's tithe while millers bid on the rest. Smugglers sometimes cut grain at night to avoid the count, hiding sacks beneath straw carts. Tradition holds that the last bundle bound becomes the Harvest King's effigy, paraded at festivals then burned to bless next year's crop.
foraging_notes: Wild relatives persist along field margins
seasonality: Annual cereal; sown in autumn and harvested in early summer
rotation_relationships: Rotated with legumes to replenish soil
fallow_notes: Fields lie fallow after two years of cereals
